from sklearn.datasets import load_boston
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.2d1b75c1:
# Independent
X = dataset.iloc[:, :-1]  # All columns except the last column

# dependent
y = dataset.iloc[:, -1]   # Only the last column
source.ce9175f8:
from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_score
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

model = LinearRegression()

# mean squared error by performing cross validation 5 times(5 experiments)
# 5 values in form of list
mse = cross_val_score(model, X, y, scoring="neg_mean_squared_error", cv=5)

# calculate mean
mean_mse = np.mean(mse)
mean_mse
source.1ab22d8d:
from sklearn.linear_model import Ridge
from sklearn.model_selection import GridSearchCV

# Use GridSearchCV => to find the value of lambda(the regularization parameter)
model = Ridge()

# Provide various different values for alpha => values always greater than zero(any finite number)
parameters = {'alpha':[1e-15, 1e-10, 1e-8, 1e-3, 1e-2, 1, 5, 10, 20, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50, 55, 100]}
ridge_regressor = GridSearchCV(model, parameters, scoring="neg_mean_squared_error", cv=5)
ridge_regressor.fit(X, y)
source.b1eb3a1c:
from sklearn.linear_model import Lasso
from sklearn.model_selection import GridSearchCV

model = Lasso()
parameters = {'alpha':[1e-15, 1e-10, 1e-8, 1e-3, 1e-2, 1, 5, 10, 20, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50, 55, 100]}
lasso_regressor = GridSearchCV(model, parameters, scoring="neg_mean_squared_error", cv=5)
lasso_regressor.fit(X, y)
source.563f48cb:
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.3, random_state=0)
prediction_lasso = lasso_regressor.predict(X_test)
prediction_ridge = ridge_regressor.predict(X_test)
